article_title: The District Hosts Kidney Disease Fundraiser
article_text:
Sioux Falls, SD

A fun night for a serious cause hopes to raise money and awareness for the National Kidney Foundation.

Cases of kidney disease are on the rise, but donor numbers stay flat. That's a problem because diabetes and high blood pressure are key risk factors for kidney failure. According to a new study, that puts one in three Americans at risk.

A March 7 fundraiser at The District Lounge in Sioux Falls aimed to change that. Doors opened at 5 p.m. for kid-friendly hors d'oeuvres and games.

Admission was $40, in return for which each guest received 100 "Kidney Dollars." Kidney Dollars could in turn be wagered on games, accumulated, and spent in a raffle. There was also a silent auction featuring cakes by local bakeries.

Guests not wishing to play could pay $10 to see musical group Goodroad take the stage at 8 p.m.

The Mardi Gras theme fit with the festive atmosphere, but the real spotlight was on kidney disease and a local family that's fighting back.

Joann Sullivan is on the board of the National Kidney Foundation, and her daughter, Anne, is in need of a transplant.

"Annie spends three hours, three days a week on dialysis, hooked into a dialysis machine, to basically keep her alive. If anybody were to give Annie this most precious give of their kidney, it will mean [going] back to a normal life," Sullivan said.

Sullivan says her daughter was born with a rare immune disorder that caused her kidneys to fail.

The average wait time for a donor kidney today is six years. The National Kidney Foundation is working to improve that by providing kidney screenings and educating patients and professionals about the transplant process.

Anne's blood type is O, but a donor doesn't have to be her type to make a difference. Volunteers of other blood types can be added to a donor "pool" for their chosen recipient.

The system works on reciprocity: if another waiting recipient should have a donor with blood type O, that donor's kidney would come to Anne, and the volunteer's organ would go to that other recipient. The pool system enables doctors to connect "chains" of recipients and their donors, helping the most people possible.

Modern laparoscopic kidney transplantations are considered safe and are only minimally invasive. Insurance and Medicare frequently pay for everything besides lodging for kidney donors, and in the Sullivan's case, the family says they would gladly cover that.

Donors may expect to remain in the hospital around three days and may be unable to work for two weeks; other than that, Sullivan says the average, healthy person who donates a kidney can expect to continue their regular lifestyle without ever noticing a difference.

You can learn more about the Sullivan's story by visiting their Facebook page.

2015 was the first year the National Kidney Foundation held this kind of fundraiser; it replaces another event known as the "Feast of the Great Chefs."

The National Kidney Foundation holds its next fundraising event March 24 at 4:30 p.m. at Carnaval Brazilian Grill in Sioux Falls. The occasion is to feature a ribbon-cutting ceremony marking The National Kidney Foundation's partnership with the Sioux Falls Chamber of Commerce and will also season of kidney walks across the region, including one in Sioux Falls on June 6. Sioux Falls will also host the National Kidney Foundation Golf Classic at Willow Run Golf Course on June 15.
